discussion.content:
SIP, H.323, and RTP are the most correct answers.
Session Initiation Protocol is used for multimedia communication sessions.
H.323 is used to define how real-time audio, video and data information is transmitted. It provides signaling, multimedia and bandwidth control mechanisms over RTP.
Real-time Transport Protocol is a packet-formatting standard for delivering audio and video over the Internet, and is popularly implemented for VoIP solutions.
NTP is incorrect; Network Time Protocol's functions are not relevant to a VoIP PBX.
SMB is incorrect; Server Message Block is a Windows protocol for sharing access to files and printers between hosts.
ICMP is incorrect; Internet Control Message Protocol is not relevant to the functions of a PBX.
IPsec is incorrect; IP security is not relevant to the function of the PBX.
RDP is incorrect; Remote Desktop Protocol features are not relevant to the function of the PBX.

Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) is used to signal and control interactive communication sessions. The uses for such sessions include voice, video, chat and instant messaging, as well as interactive games and virtual reality.

H. 323 was the first VoIP standard to adopt the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) standard Real-time Transport Protocol (RTP) to transport audio and video over IP networks.


Real-time transport protocol (RTP) is a way of structuring data packets so that they can be delivered across the internet at lightning speeds and reassembled into a smooth flowing stream suitable for delivering voice or multimedia in a natural way. Without such a protocol, voice over IP would be impossible
I would have got two right. What is RTP?

questions.question_text:
A network technician is considering opening ports on the firewall for an upcoming VoIP PBX implementation. Which of the following protocols is the technician
MOST likely to consider? (Choose three.)

discussion.content: It's a weird and confusing question since A and D are both possible answers. I initially thought D was the correct answer as well. But after reading the question again and again I realized that the main point right here is that in a SOHO network, a router would be much more of a necessity than a proxy server. That's what makes me lean more towards A.
A, cause is a SOHO (Small Office, Home Office) network. Remember all come integrated in the router.
I appreciate those of you pointing me towards the SOHO point of the question. Yes router is going to be the correct choice because SOHO routers usually have DNS settings configurable.

From my understanding answers BCD are good for transmissions coming into the SOHO network. Here they want to direct SOHO traffic to a specific DNS server. This meaning transmissions are leaving the network. A router will work here.
I believe the answer is proxy server because it acts as a gateway between the users and the internet. Keyword is the new DNS server that is also a webpage.

comments.content: No where in the question does it state anything about a webpage. Router is the answer because a SOHO router does what a DHCP server does, tell each client which DNS server to use.

discussion.content: I believe A - Router is the correct answer. Always watch for your clue. In this question, the clue is SOHO network. D is a trap, the detractor.
I think A is right because I'm thinking of DCHP

comments.content: Agreed. I've done it several times myself. It's as simple as updating the DNS server settings in the router.

discussion.content: I may be wrong but I believe that the answer is Router. Since you are directing 'all clients' to the same DNS. Within a router you can set the DNS server settings which would be the solution to this question I guess? :)

comments.content: whoa a year ago comment huh, crazy, but it's a router because snat or port forwarding would direct the traffic to the DNS Server.
ehh maybe I'am wrong about why but still think it's a router
i think the answer is proxy Server too. why would it be a Router though?

discussion.content:
I say ‘Proxy Server’. That’s what their used for !
Each client is configured with the PS address and voila !

questions.question_text: A technician wants to configure a SOHO network to use a specific public DNS server. Which of the following network components should the technician configure to point all clients on a network to a new DNS server?

discussion.content: Geofencing is “the use of GPS or RFID technology to create a virtual geographic boundary, enabling software to trigger a response when a mobile device enters or leaves a particular area.”

comments.content: The only problem with option C is you don't want external people accessing your network. Option D is much more secure.

discussion.content: Mac Filtering allows only people with specific IP addresses to access the network. The question states that employees upon entering the company can immediately access the wifi, so a pre-shared key has to be the answer. Open wireless is for anybody especially people who are just guests of the company to access the network. Geofencing is for location services that has nothing to do with connecting to the wifi. That is why the answer is C. Pre-Shared Key.

if something was mentioned about phones already configurated the answer will be geofencing , since there is no clue it has to pre shared key otherwise every one with a phone can connect easily to the company internet
I really think its geofencing

I think it's C. 
If you use Geofencing, every devices will can connect in the network. If you use pre-shared key the company can give the company-own deviced already configured. 
Acho que a chave aqui é: "company-own "

The action here is location sensitive. Even when they have the pre-shared key, they cannot connect until they cross the geo fence. Therefore, “B” is the only correct answer. - - As for what’s right for the exam, there’s no tellin’

comments.content: But also, this access is for "employees with company-owned mobile device" so the Pre-Shared key would most likely be already configured when the device was provided to the employee.

I don't think its geo-fencing because your wireless network should only extend to the borders of your building. Once employees enter the building (ie: Wireless coverage area), their devices authenticate automatically via "Pre-Shared Key"

discussion.content: I think It's Geofencing since the question clearly states "connect automatically to the corporate wireless network upon entering the facility."

The answer is geofencing. Pre-shared key requires authentication, hence you need to input a shared password. Geofencing is something your device does upon entering and exiting a location. Remember answers to these questions can be wrong.

I agree that in the real world "Open Wireless" would be a terrible option, but the only info given in this question is you want your employees to access it. An open network grants that most easily. It doesn't say you don't want everyone else to have access. (Again this should NOT be done in the real world, but for the sake of the question i would say open 
network)

I think D. Mac filtering is the correct answer.
A. Is open to everyone including guests, so it's a no.
B. Does a good job of limiting the geographical area to "upon entering the facility" but doesn't necessarily restrict non "company-owned devices". Be is not the BEST option.
C. The key will only be shared amongst the employees but this doesn't ensure "company-owned devices only" since employees could use the key on thier personal devices. C could be a good option only if the employees could be trusted.
D. This will definitely unsure that correct devices are allowed to connect to the network. The BEST option.

I know you are asking, what about the whole "upon entering the faculty" specification? Well, AP's will be positioned and power levels set such that the range is within the specified area.

Geofencing is a location-based service in which an app or other software uses GPS, RFID, Wi-Fi or cellular data to trigger a pre-programmed action when a mobile device or RFID tag enters or exits a virtual boundary set up around a geographical location
Both PSK and geofencing can be used. The question asked for the BEST option. Which in IMO, is pre shared keys.

It seems to me that correct answer is B. Geofencing.
https://www.computerworld.com/article/3528795/geofencing-what-is-it.html
I'm going with C because it says "BEST"
Why isn't this geofencing?
Why wouldn't this one be Mac filtering?

comments.content: If you have 300 employees for instance it is a waste of time to use mac filtering. Geofencing is “the use of GPS or RFID technology to create a virtual geographic boundary, enabling software to trigger a response when a mobile device enters or leaves a particular area.”

questions.question_text:
A company wishes to allow employees with company-owned mobile devices to connect automatically to the corporate wireless network upon entering the facility.
Which of the following would BEST accomplish this objective?

A network engineer for a manufacturing company is implementing a wireless network that provides reliable coverage throughout the facility. There are several large, electric, motorized machines installed on the shop floor for automating the manufacturing process. These machines are known to be significant sources of
RF interference. Which of the following frequencies should the wireless network use to MINIMIZE this interference?

discussion.content: When multiple devices operate on the same frequency, there is usually interference that can affect the signal's characteristics at the receiving point and reduce the connection speed. ... Overall, 5GHz WiFi frequency experiences fewer interferences from other devices than WiFi connections using 2.4GHz

Closely tied to latency, which was discussed earlier, jitter differs in that the
length of the delay between received packets differs. While the sender continues
to transmit packets in a continuous stream and space them evenly apart, the delay between packets received varies instead of remaining constant. This can be
caused by network congestion, improper queuing, or configuration errors.

Thumbs up Emago,
Keywords here: different delay times
thanks for good explan
Thanks Emago, Great explanation
Shouldn't it be B???

comments.content:
"Jitter is the uneven arrival of packets. For example, imagine a VoIP conversation where packet 1 arrives at a destination router. Then, 20 ms later, packet 2 arrives. After another 70 ms, packet 3 arrives, and then packet 4 arrives 20 ms behind packet 3. This variation in arrival times (that is, variable delay) is not dropping packets, but the jitter might be interpreted by the listener as dropped packets."

"Latency: Refers to the time lapse between sending or requesting
information and the time it takes to return. As you might expect, satellite communication experiences high latency due to the distance it has to travel.
[...]
Closely tied to latency, which was discussed earlier, jitter differs in that the length of the delay between received packets differs. While the sender continues to transmit packets in a continuous stream and space them evenly apart, the delay between packets received varies instead of remaining constant. This can be caused by network congestion, improper queuing, or configuration errors."

questions.question_text: A corporate manager says wireless phones do not work properly inside the main building. After a troubleshooting process, the network administrator detects that the voice packets are arriving on the wireless phones with different delay times. Which of the following performance issues is the company facing?
